items.title: Bug in Printing to Console using ROS_INFO
items.body:
### Problem description

I think there is a bug in how docker prints information to terminal, at least with respect to ROS_INFO. For a simple ROS HelloWorld program that uses just ROS_INFO, the message isn't printed; but if I add a `cout` message, then both print. The fact that ROS_INFO prints **if cout is present** leads me to believe this isn't a ROS bug.

Relevant info:

Dockerfile
```
FROM ros:kinetic
```

docker-compose.yml
```
version: '2'

services:
    master:
        build: .
        container_name: master
        command: roscore

    t1:
        build: .
        container_name: t1
        environment:
            - "ROS_HOSTNAME=t1"
            - "ROS_MASTER_URI=http://master:11311"
        volumes:
            - ~/catkin_ws:/repo
        command: /repo/docker-command.sh
```

docker-command.sh
```
#!/bin/bash

# wait for roscore
sleep 2 						# at least 2

cp -r /repo/devel/lib/trial /opt/ros/kinetic/lib
source /ros_entrypoint.sh
rosrun trial HelloWorld

# don't stop container
while true; do sleep 1000; done
```

HelloWorld.cpp
```
#include <ros/ros.h>

using namespace std;

int main(int argc, char** argv) {
	ros::init(argc, argv, "trial");
	
	ROS_INFO("Hello World!");
	cout << "Hello World 2!" << endl;

	ros::spin();
	return 0;
}
```

Output with only ROS_INFO print (commenting the line `cout << "Hello World 2!" << endl;`)
```
nathan@nathan-ma-vm1:~/catkin_ws$ docker-compose up
Starting master
Starting t1
Attaching to t1, master
t1        | [rospack] Error: package 'trial' not found
t1        | find: ‘’: No such file or directory
^CGracefully stopping... (press Ctrl+C again to force)
```

Output with both prints
```
nathan@nathan-ma-vm1:~/catkin_ws$ docker-compose up
Starting master
Starting t1
Attaching to master, t1
t1        | [rospack] Error: package 'trial' not found
t1        | find: ‘’: No such file or directory
t1        | [ INFO] [1524672395.044437305]: Hello World!
t1        | Hello World 2!
^CGracefully stopping... (press Ctrl+C again to force)
```

items.title: Fix JSON example on webhooks page
items.body:
### Proposed changes
Correct the JSON example on the Webhooks page. The comment_count parameter in the JSON body is a number, not a string.

items.title: Healthcheck fail fast feature during container start up
items.body:
### Problem description

Current [`HEALTHCHECK`](https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/builder/#healthcheck) command does not allow some sort of _fail fast_ functionality.

Let's assume some big web app that typically starts up in about 10 minutes. The following config seems to be your suggestion given the documentation:

Dockerfile:
```
HEALTHCHECK --interval=10s --timeout=3s --start-period=10m\
  CMD curl -f http://localhost/ || exit 1
```

Now imagine that due to some configuration error the app deploy fails 15s after the docker is run. The web server (Tomcat, Jboss etc.) continue to run though, so the docker container stays up.
Then I would have to wait approx. 10 minutes to know that something went wrong.

### Suggestions for a fix

Maybe implement third state among the current two

- 0: success - the container is healthy and ready for use
- 1: unhealthy - the container is not working correctly

to indicate the startup stage. Or to indicate some critical unrecoverable failure, that marks container unhealthy even within the `--start-period` period.

Or do not reinvent the wheel and use [2 different healthchecks](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/configure-pod-container/configure-liveness-readiness-probes/) like the Kubernetes.

items.title: Fix double-hyphen typographic bug
items.body:
Signed-off-by: Misty Stanley-Jones <misty@apache.org>

Fixes #4178 

This introduces two changes in the `_config.yml`. One change is a tweak to Kramdown's config, and the other is an update to the version of Github Pages that is used for builds invoked by `jekyll build` (local builds, Netlify, etc). For our actual live deploy, we actually already use the latest version of the Github Pages gem, but don't yet have the tweaked config. The changes to `_config.yml` will need to be backported back to archive branches, possibly all the way back to 17.03, if you care about fixing the typography problem in those.

1. introduce rethinkcli non-interactive mode for DTR 2.2-2.5

    - Removes the need to precisely position cursor when copying out commands to not copy prompt

2. ported #6061 and #5450 to 2.5 docs

    - `current_issues` is still the most interesting table from a membership troubleshooting standpoint

4. Rendered docs locally and tested 2.2/2.3 commands with copy-pasted into DTR 2.3.5

items.title: BSOD on Windows 10 with Hyper-V Enabled
items.body:
### Problem description

<!--Briefly describe the problem that you found.
    Only DOCUMENTATION issues should be filed here.
    For general questions, go to https://forums.docker.com/. -->

Trying to folow the instructions found at ["Set Up Your Swarm"](https://docs.docker.com/get-started/part4/#set-up-your-swarm) causes Windows 10 to fatally crash with a BSOD (Blue Screen of Death). This is a [long-time](https://www.virtualbox.org/ticket/15780), known [Virtualbox bug](https://www.virtualbox.org/ticket/16801), which Oracle (and I) assign blame to Microsoft.

*My issue* is that the documentation should be updated to reflect this critical error. (It's very unfortunate, because no one on windows 10 can complete the getting started guide.)

I have separately filed a [Docker Issue ](https://github.com/docker/machine/issues/4151)for the technical problem.

### Problem location

<!-- Help us find the problem quickly by choosing one of these. -->

- I saw a problem on the following URL: <https://docs.docker.com/get-started/part4/#set-up-your-swarm>

### Project version(s) affected

<!-- If this problem only affects specific versions of a project (like Docker
     Engine 1.13), tell us here. The fix may need to take that into account. -->

docker-machine.exe version 0.10.0, build 76ed2a6

### Suggestions for a fix

<!--If you have specific ideas about how we can fix this, let us know. -->
Suggest some warning that attempting to run VirtualBox with Hyper-V enabled will cause a BSOD. Ironically, Docker requires Hyper-V enabled for itself to run.

<!-- To improve this template, edit the .github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md file -->

items.title: Error: invalid mount config for type "bind": bind source path does not exist
items.body:
File: [get-started/part5.md](https://docs.docker.com/get-started/part5/), CC @johndmulhausen

**Step 2** in the **Persistent Data** section where we need to create a `./data` folder on the manager node, isn't working for me because the Redis container outputs the error message `invalid mount config for type "bind": bind source path does not exist` after deploying the stack. But if I also create a `./data` folder on my host (Mac), along with the data folder on the vm (VirtualBox), it will work. Although, no data is stored in the Mac folder. I'm not sure what is the correct way to handle this, probably I had to end my session and connect to the virtual machine again after creating the folder? *I use the docker toolbox setup (on an older Mac)*.

items.title: "Segmentation fault" when generating the site again after editing a file
items.body:
### Problem description
After cloning the repository, the site is successfully generated as shown.

> $ bundle exec jekyll serve
> Configuration file: E:/GIT/docker.github.io/_config.yml
>             Source: E:/GIT/docker.github.io
>        Destination: E:/GIT/docker.github.io/_site
>  Incremental build: enabled
>       Generating...
>                     done in 544.006 seconds.
>  Auto-regeneration: enabled for 'E:/GIT/docker.github.io'
>     Server address: http://127.0.0.1:4000
>   Server running... press ctrl-c to stop.
> 

After this I go my **docker.github.io** folder and make edits to, say the **global-header.html** file. I try to regenerate the site again but the site isn't generated and it stops with the following **Segmentation fault** error. 
I would be grateful if someone could point out what I'm doing wrong here. 

**PS:** Apologies if this is the wrong place but I couldn't find any category related to this error in https://forums.docker.com/ hence posting it here.

> $ bundle exec jekyll serve
> Configuration file: E:/GIT/docker.github.io/_config.yml
>             Source: E:/GIT/docker.github.io
>        Destination: E:/GIT/docker.github.io/_site
>  Incremental build: enabled
>       Generating...
> **Segmentation fault**
>

Requesting a tech review, especially in regard to old text (and possible links to new headings):

- If using `overlay2`, do you need to install `device-mapper-persistent-data` and `lvm2`?

items.title: Add landing pages at a couple places under /datacenter/
items.body:
URL: /datacenter/

Suggested improvement to the doc tree for EE products

Given that UCP & DTR docs are at these URLs: https://docs.docker.com/datacenter/ucp/2.1/guides/ and https://docs.docker.com/datacenter/dtr/2.2/guides/ : it would be nice to fill out the intermediate links so they don't return 404s. People somewhat expect the intermediate links on the way to deep links to be populated with data. Clearly someone had some organization in mind when creating the link structure, so "use the force", as they say. 

That is, 

- list all the datacenter products on https://docs.docker.com/datacenter , e.g. UCP and DTR, with links to the lower level "product specific" page
- for each product page, list each of the versions available, e.g. on https://docs.docker.com/datacenter/ucp, list 2.0, 2.1, etc.
- keep the doc trees for older versions
- if there is some other material than "guides" on the level of an individual release, list it on the version page. Otherwise, get rid of the intermediate link to "guides"

Sometimes, Docker Cloud autotests will return this in the logs at the end of a successful test, when running in your own nodes:

```
Tests in docker-compose.test.yml succeeded
Build finished
ERROR: Build failed: Build finished
ERROR: Build failed with exit code 0
ERROR: Tests in 'dev' (ffb81ed5) failed in 0:09:00
```

items.title: Speed up site rendering for authors
items.body:
There are multiple vectors affecting site performance and here I'm trying to take on many of them:

1. tree.html is being called hundreds of times per build and each call is a recursive loop. This is replaced by JS logic that reads a jsonified version of the TOC at load time (note: not page ready time), injecting the TOC HTML using pure JS, no jQuery. This is faster-than-ajax processing as it does not involve waiting for jQuery to load and realize the the document is ready, nor does it involve making XmlHttpRequests asynchronously; liquid pre-prints a JSON object with the TOC in it and pure JS immediately rips it apart and injects it into the HTML as soon as it's read. The HTML is built up in an Array that is appended to using `push()` (as string concatenation does more memory/CPU work), and this Array is `join()`ed at injection time. It's as fast as can possibly be done with JS, and I think there is no difference between this and the current site. Here's the JSON TOC: https://deploy-preview-5241--docker-docs.netlify.com/js/toc.js -- poke around on Netlify and see the speed for yourself.

2. An outdated version of GH Pages is being used; this upgrades us from 137 > 147

3. We're hand-rolling the sitemap.xml file, when there's a perfectly good plugin for it included with GH Pages. 

4. Our use of plugins and other such bells and whistles is creating bottlenecks because plugins are too stupid to know which file got updated; now there is `_config_authoring.yml`, which takes out all plugins, skips applying several site configurations, skips most of the per-page ("scoped") variable setting, skips sitemap generation altogether, and skips any attempts to process Jekyll collections, all of which massively improves the incremental build performance when editing individual files.

Naturally, the Dockerfile/production build process will use the full `_config.yml` that has these all turned on.

To use: 
```
jekyll serve --config _config_authoring.yml
```

## Results

## Editing a single page

Before these changes, a full site rebuild was triggered, ~300 seconds, depending on my machine

Now: 9 seconds on my Windows machine. Haven't tested Mac yet.

## Full site rebuild

Before: ~300 seconds (using `_config.yml`)

Now: 148.168 seconds on my Windows machine (using `_config_authoring.yml`). Haven't tested Mac yet.

Edit: Have tested on Mac, build time is 51 seconds on my Macbook Pro!

Unfortunately incremental building seems not to work due to reasons beyond what this PR addresses but with a 50 second build time we are significantly reducing refresh time while maintaining status quo on incremental builds.

Will file a jekyll bug asking for help once this PR is merged. At the point where we're using the latest github pages with no plugins, it should be working.

items.title: Best Practices - Possibly outdated note
items.body:
The best practices page refers to an unresolved bug that looks like it was recently closed. I didn't look closely at the issue or the resolution, but noticed that it was closed on 9/20. It may be worth keeping an eye on it and possibly cleaning up / removing this note. 

> **Note**: Due to an [unresolved bug](https://github.com/golang/go/issues/13548) in the Go archive/tar package's handling of sparse files, attempting to create a user with a sufficiently large UID inside a Docker container can lead to disk exhaustion as `/var/log/faillog` in the container layer is filled with NUL (\0) characters.  Passing the `--no-log-init` flag to useradd works around this issue.  The Debian/Ubuntu `adduser` wrapper does not support the `--no-log-init` flag and should be avoided.

Certainly not critical, but since the bug had been outstanding for almost 2 years, I thought it was worth pointing out.

File: [engine/userguide/eng-image/dockerfile_best-practices.md](https://docs.docker.com/engine/userguide/eng-image/dockerfile_best-practices/), CC @mstanleyjones
